sen.j: 政井 みね（まさい みね、1888年2月3日 - 1909年11月20日）は、日本の労働者。
sen.e: Mine MASAI (February 3, 1888 - November 20, 1909) was a Japanese worker.

sen.j: 日本近代化を陰で支えた労働者の一人であり、かつて野麦峠を越えた女工哀史を語る際に欠かせない人物である。
sen.e: She was one of the anonymous workers who contributed to the modernization of Japan, and the essential person to tell sad stories of factory girls who once went over the Nomugi Pass.

sen.j: 政井みねは岐阜県吉城郡河合村 (岐阜県)（現飛騨市河合町角川）の農村部に生まれた。
sen.e: Mine MASAI was born in an agricultural community area of Kawai Village, Yoshiki District in Gifu Prefecture (Tsunogawa, Kawai-cho, Hida City, Gif Prefecture, as of now).

sen.j: 当時はまだ貧しい農村部では、出稼ぎに出る事で食費を浮かし家計を助けるという「口べらし（口減らし）」が一般に行われており、みねも家庭の生活費を助けるために信州の岡谷市へ出稼ぎに出る事となった。
sen.e: In those days, it was still common in poor agricultural community areas to work away from home to "reduce the mouths to feed" in order to help a household to reduce cost of food, and thus Mine was sent to Okaya City in Shinshu to help her family to reduce their cost of living.

In those days, it was still common in poor farming community to let members go out to town and work for reducing the mouths to feed (it had been called 'Kuchi-berashi'), and Mine was also sent to Okaya City in Shinshu to help her family.

sen.j: 明治政府による富国強兵のもと、外貨獲得のために日本の近代化を支えたものは水の豊富な長野県諏訪地域における製糸業であり、みねを始め多くの女性労働者が家族との別れを惜しみつつ野麦峠を越え出稼ぎに出る，当時はそんな時代だったのである。
sen.e: Under fukoku kyohei (fortifying the country, strengthening the military) policy of the Meiji Government, the silk-reeling industry in Suwa area, Nagano Prefecture, where richly endowed with water, supported modernization of Japan to earn foreign currency, and many female workers like Mine reluctantly left their family home and went over the Nomugi Pass for work - that was a life in those days.

sen.j: みねが100人以上の工女とともに信州・岡谷に向かったのは14歳になった1903年2月、交通の難所として名高い野麦峠の中でも最も過酷な条件となる頃である。
sen.e: 14 year-old Mine departed to Okaya in Shinshu with more than 100 female workers in February, 1903, and it was the time when the weather condition becomes worst to cross the Nomugi Pass, which was famous as a dangerous spot for transportation.

sen.e: The remaining snow brutally cut the feet of the girls like a knife.

sen.j: また、足を踏み外して谷に滑落する者、峠の宿（お助け茶屋）に入りきらずに吹雪のなか外で夜を明かす者もいたという。
sen.e: Some of them took a misstep and fell into valley, and some could not find a space in a shelter teahouse at the Pass (Otasuke-chaya) and had to spend a night outside in snowstorm.

sen.j: 製糸工場、山一林組で働く事となったみねを待っていたものは、現在とは比較にならないほど劣悪な環境下での労働であった。
sen.e: Mine was assigned to work for a silk mill, Yamaichi-Hayashi Gumi, where she faced the harsh working condition that was nothing to compare to the modern days.

sen.j: 15時間にも及ぶ長時間労働に加え蒸し暑さや悪臭などが漂う工場での労働は生半可なものではなく、工女の逃亡を防ぐため工場に鉄製の桟が張られているという監獄にも近い状態であったが、みねを含め多くの少女たちは自分の賃金で実家を助けるため、また工場が休みとなる正月に両親と再会できることを信じ、歯を食いしばって耐えたのである。
sen.e: In addition to a long working hours of over 15 hours, humidity and foul odor of the factory made working there even more difficult, and also the factory was surrounded by iron fences to prevent the female workers from escaping like a jail; however, a lot of girls including Mine endured with gritted teeth in order to help their family with their wages, believing they would see their parents again when the factory would be closed for the new year holiday.

sen.j: 時は経ち、工女の模範となって年収が百円を超えた（通称、百円工女）みねに突然訪れた病気、それは重度の腹膜炎であった。
sen.e: Time passed and Mine became an exemplar of the factory and her annual income reached more than 100 yen (these workers were called "100 yen female worker"), however she suffered a sudden illness of severe peritonitis.

sen.j: 知らせを受け、みねを引き取りに来た兄・辰次郎は松本市で入院する事を勧めたが、自らの死を既に悟ったのであろうか、みねは故郷の飛騨へ帰りたいと兄の提案を拒否した。
sen.e: Receiving the news, Mine's elder brother Tasujiro came to pick her up and suggested her to stay in a hospital in Matsumoto City, however, Mine probably knew her death was close and refused her brother's proposal and decided to go back to her hometown, Hida.

sen.e: On their way to Hida, when they arrived to the teahouse where many workers lost their lives, Mine was pleased and said "Oh, I can see Hida", then breathed her last breath.

sen.j: この史実は山本茂実の小説、「あゝ野麦峠」で有名になったもので、野麦峠にある慰霊碑や飛騨市河合町角川の専勝寺にある墓には、死後100年近く経った現在でもその死を悼んで訪れる人がいる。
sen.e: This historical fact was made famous in the novel "Ah, Nomugi Toge" (Oh, the Nomugi Pass) by Shigemi YAMAMOTO, and after 100 years of Mine's death still many people visit the memorial in the Nomugi Pass and her grave in Sensho-ji temple in Tsunogawa, Kawai-cho, Hida City to commemorate her death.
